title: Strange behavior after midnight - code executes on its own
body:
## Expected Behavior
The application should remain idle when no user interaction is present.

## Actual Behavior
Every night at exactly **midnight**, the application starts executing code blocks that aren't even in the repository. The logs show functions being called that don't exist in our codebase:

```javascript
// This function appears in logs but doesn't exist anywhere
function summonTheOldOnes() {
  console.log("Ph'nglui mglw'nafh Cthulhu R'lyeh wgah'nagl fhtagn");
  return 666;
}
```

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Deploy the application
2. Wait until midnight (00:00:00 UTC)
3. Check the application logs
4. Notice mysterious function calls and memory consumption spikes

## Environment
- **OS:** Ubuntu 20.04 LTS (running on servers in an old data center basement)
- **Node.js:** v18.13.0
- **Last known working version:** Unknown (this started happening after we moved to the new office built on an ancient burial ground)

## Additional Context
The office cleaning staff refuse to work past 11 PM now. They claim they hear "typing sounds" coming from the server room even when no one is there.

**UPDATE:** I just checked the git blame... some of these mysterious commits are attributed to users who left the company *years* ago. Their accounts have been deactivated.

**UPDATE 2:** The functions seem to be summoning something. Memory usage hits exactly 666 MB every time.

labels.name: midnight-only
labels.description: Only occurs during the witching hour

comments.body:
This has to be a joke, right? There's no way code can execute itself. Have you checked for:

- Scheduled cron jobs?
- Webhook triggers?
- Time-based CI/CD pipelines?

Occam's razor suggests a much simpler explanation than... whatever this is supposed to be.

@skeptical_dev I thought the same thing initially. But I've checked:

- ‚úÖ No cron jobs scheduled
- ‚úÖ No webhooks configured 
- ‚úÖ CI/CD is disabled for this branch
- ‚úÖ No scheduled tasks in the application

The strangest part? The server's system clock shows the correct time, but the application logs timestamp these events as occurring in **1692**.

Here's a screenshot of the logs:

![Mysterious logs showing 1692 timestamps](https://i.imgur.com/spooky_logs.png)

I'm not making this up.

This looks like a sophisticated attack. Someone might have:

1. Compromised your deployment pipeline
2. Injected malicious code during the build process
3. Set up a time-based trigger

I recommend:
- [ ] Immediately isolate the affected servers
- [ ] Run a full security audit
- [ ] Check for any unauthorized access to your repositories
- [ ] Scan for rootkits and malware

**Do NOT ignore this.** The "666 MB" memory usage is particularly concerning - that's way too specific to be coincidental.

I've been programming for 30 years, and I've seen this before.

Back in '99, we had a similar issue at my previous company. Turned out the previous development team had embedded some... unusual dependencies. The building was constructed on an old cemetery, and the electromagnetic fields interfered with the server hardware in ways we couldn't explain.

We ended up having to perform a complete "code exorcism" - basically rewriting everything from scratch on new hardware.

Some things in this industry can't be debugged with traditional methods. üïØÔ∏è

*Sometimes, you just have to accept that not everything has a logical explanation.*

I'll take a look at this tomorrow. In the meantime:

1. **DO NOT** run the application between 11:30 PM and 12:30 AM
2. Keep the server room lights on at all times
3. Place a circle of salt around the servers (I'm serious)
4. If you hear Latin chanting from the speakers, immediately pull the power cables

I'll bring my debugging toolkit and some... specialized equipment.

---

*"There are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, than are dreamt of in your philosophy."* - Shakespeare

But also: *"It's always DNS."* - Ancient DevOps Proverb

Let's solve this methodically. üëª
